It is now five fixtures without a victory for Eddie Howe and his team and while nobody would suggest that pre-season results count for very much, Newcastle United cannot be accused of needlessly hoarding momentum.
After a difficult summer off the pitch, the return of football to St Jamesâ€™ Park felt like a minor source of relief in that it shifted the conversation â€” for 90 minutes at least â€” away from the absent Alexander Isak and a frustrating transfer window.

No dissent was aimed towards Isak, who has expressed his desire to leave Tyneside and has been the subject of a failed Â£110million ($148m) bid from Liverpool, but this 2-2 draw with Espanyol did not quite resemble a statement of intent. It followed another draw with Tottenham Hotspur and defeats to Team K-League, Arsenal, and Celtic.
Howeâ€™s side went behind to a long-range goal from Edu Exposito and then equalised through Matt Targett, who was heavily involved for reasons good and bad. Aaron Ramsdale, the goalkeeper, saved a penalty on his debut, there was a 77th-minute goal from Jacob Murphy, and a late reply from Kike Garcia, the Espanyol substitute.
Newcastle play their final warm-up match, again at St Jamesâ€™ Park, against Atletico Madrid on Saturday. Their Premier League campaign begins with a trip to Aston Villa seven days later, but in terms of new players and some big decisions, there is much work still to do.
Where is the â€œdynamismâ€ that Howe called for?
The last time Eddie Howe sat in the hot seat in the St Jamesâ€™ press room was on the final day of last season. Newcastle lost 1-0 to Everton, but they had finished fifth in the Premier League and qualified for the Champions League. The head coach was already thinking about what was next.
When Howe spoke about transfers, it did feel as though the media or supporters were his primary audience. He talked about a need to â€œbe dynamic. We have to be ready to complete things very, very quickly because good players donâ€™t hang around for longâ€.
That was May 25. Three months later, Newcastle have signed Ramsdale and Anthony Elanga, but they have also missed out on a plethora of signings â€” Bryan Mbeumo, James Trafford, Joao Pedro, Liam Delap, Hugo Ekitike, Benjamin Sesko â€” either through being rejected or gazumped. Paul Mitchell, the sporting director, has long since left and is yet to be replaced.
â€œDynamicâ€ does not feel like the right description of how things have unfolded.
Howe was asked about that, about what has (or has not) happened. He did not cast any blame.
â€œI think the club has been dynamic, I think the club has been proactive,â€ he insisted. â€œWe have tried, but through no fault of anyone thatâ€™s working behind the scenes, we havenâ€™t been able to close some deals that, at one stage, looked very close. They just got away from us, but that can happen to any deal until itâ€™s signed, sealed and delivered.

We didnâ€™t sign many last summer and everyone said it was a disastrous window and how PSR is affecting our long-term success, and we went on to have one of the best seasons in recent memory. But, obviously, if you get it right, it can take your squad forward to a different area. We are very keen to add new stimulus to the group. Letâ€™s see what happens.â€
How was Aaron Ramsdaleâ€™s debut?
There was one new signing on display, two if you include Park Seung-soo, the young South Korean winger who joined from Suwon Bluewings last month and made a couple of lively cameo appearances on Newcastleâ€™s tour to east Asia.
In terms of senior players, it was Ramsdale, fresh from agreeing a season-long loan from Southampton, a deal which includes an option to become permanent. The 27-year-old was not Howeâ€™s first-choice target, but after a year-long pursuit of Trafford, Newcastle lost out to Manchester City, which has been a familiar kind of story.
With Martin Dubravka moving to Burnley, Ramsdale will vie for a place with Nick Pope, who is the current number one.
Saving a penalty will do his cause no harm. Ramsdale had little chance with Expositoâ€™s 17th-minute goal, which was struck with venom from outside the box, but he got down quickly and with confidence to repel Javier Puadoâ€™s kick from the spot, a big moment in a low-key game. There was also a lovely late save from a Tyrhys Dolan effort before Espanyolâ€™s equaliser.

With Englandâ€™s Lewis Hall at left-back and starting his first match since suffering a foot injury in February, Targett began against Espanyol in the centre of midfield, a development which was both unexpected and proved very eventful. Letâ€™s call it an interesting experiment.

At least his team-mate Fabian Schar was glad to have Targett around after the full-backâ€™s fictional stranding.
The return of Hall, whose development was one of the highlights of last season, was very timely.
